channel.title: Mission Nutrition
channel.description: Healthy Body + Healthy Mind = Happy Life

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
In 2010, after moving from NYC to Spain, I realized my taste buds were changing. Not only was I turned off by sweet food, but I was disgusted by it. It wasn't until three years later I realized that during my lifestyle transition, I unintentionally cut my sugar addiction. This began my journey into the world of nutrition.
People often ask me how I lost weight. This is a space where I can share my eating choices and nutritional knowledge so you, too, can feel good!

item.title: The truth behind Starbucks fraps
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: I used to drink Starbucks frappuccinos like they were going out of style.  I'd have them all the time as a snack because I thought orering "lite" meant it was healthy. Little did I know that the ingredients used in the syrup are actually pretty dangerous. Ingredients of the base (not including sugar & whipped cream): Light Coffee Frappuccino Syrup (US version): Water, sugar, Erythritol (E968), Natural Flavors, Salt, Carageenan (E407), Xanthan Gum (E415), Maltodextrin, Preservative: Potassium Sorbate (E202), Citric Acid (E330), Reb A, Color: Caramel (E150d, E150b) Coffee Frappuccino Syrup: Sugar, Water, Natural and Artificial Flavor, Xanthan Gum (E415), Preservative: Potassium Sorbate (E202), Citric Acid (E330), Caramel Color (E150) Red= not good for you. Specifically: Xantham gum: An industrial processed product/thickener/emulsifier that can cause bloating. Caramel color: Used to add coloring, but doesn't add taste or nutritional value. The UN categorizes caramel color into 4 classes; the one found in Starbucks' frap is Class IV, the most dangerous kind. It is made by heating ammonia and sulfites under high pressure, creating a carcinogenic (re: cancerous) compound- specifically, lung, liver, and thyroid cancer. Coke and Pepsi both changed their formulas & removed caramel color when thousands of cancer deaths were linked to the consumption of their sodas.  It's also banned in California. It's also found in Starbucks' "nutritious" Oatmeal. Having this on the FDA's list of approved additives totally delegitimizes the FDA, in my opinion, but that's a story for another day. Fraps also have insane amounts of sugar- up to 78g! I haven't had a Starbucks frap since I learned about this. The beauty is that by avoiding these seriously unhealthy foods, your body goes back to its equilibrium weight. It's a win-win. [sources: Yani Hari & Cristina Goyanes @ Livestrong]

item.title: Sugar: An intro
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
Sugar seems to be all over the news these days. From NPR* to ABC News**, who claimed that bananas were officially deemed too high in sugar for monkeys- yes, monkeys -it seems like you can't read about nutrition without reading about sugar. What's the deal- is it just a transient hype? Another substance to target in our quest to lose weight? Or is this for realz?
My food passion and exploratory journey into nutrition actually began about 7 months after moving to Spain, in April 2011, when I realized that I no longer craved sugar. Ever. "That's happening to me too! And it happened to my sister here!" my Canadian friend told me, and I was immediately curious- what's driving this, or is it completely coincidence?
It wasn't until almost 2 years later when I read David Gillespie's "Sweet Poison" book on sugar that I realized there was a science behind it all: the less sugar you have, the less sugar you crave. Of course, it's more complicated than that (stay tuned!) Having been in an environment with less sugar additives, I simply stopped craving it- and lost some pounds along the way.
To get started, take this quiz to see if you're addicted to sugar. It's a little silly...but I'd say important questions to ask yourself are: Do you think about sugar or dessert even if you're not hungry? Do you 'crash' at 3pm every day and look for something sweet to eat or drink to help? Are you unable to celebrate a birthday or event without eating something sweet?
And for those extra curious readers out there, a simple guide to sugars: http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2014/jan/14/sugar-guide-forms-sweet-calories-sweetener
 
*http://www.npr.org/blogs/thesalt/2014/01/15/262741403/why-sugar-makes-us-feel-so-good)
**http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-01-15/zoo-stops-giving-bananas-to-monkeys-for-27health-reasons27/5201310

item.title: Sugar's bad. I get it. What about

item.title: Not all frozen foods are created equal
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: Most of my friends eat frozen foods and think they're being healthy. If it's from Trader Joe's, it must be healthy, right? Nope. I've been tempted to say that all frozen foods are bad. But upon more research, I realized that would be misleading. Here's the deal, yo. When you're shopping for frozen foods, ignore the labels. Look for the sugar content and ingredients. Example: Kashi Mayan Harvest Bake All natural, 9g protein, 8g fiber...looks delicious AND healthy! I always get suspicious when they make health claims, though. Real foods shouldn't have to sell themselves. Now let's check the nutrition label: 19g of sugar?! That's about 5 teaspoons of sugar. Women are supposed to have no more than 6 teaspoons/day, men 9 teaspoons/day. Fun fact: type in "how many teaspoons of sugar daily" into the google search box and it'll pop right up. And for the ingredients, where do I even start?!

item.title: Carrots with Soy Sauce
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: Ahh, there's nothing like being inspired by your friend's delicious, healthy lunch! Michaela, an IEP colleague originally from Bratislava, capital of Slovakia*, is just awesome, and so is this recipe she gave me: -Chop up carrots and onion -Sautee in olive oil about 3-4 minutes -add soy sauce, salt, pepper -let sit about 10 minutes Ta-da! For more details on Bratislava, contact Amy Gurka.

item.title: I'm tired
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
I'm tired of looking at the ingredients of everything I eat. I'm tired of walking into a store or supermarket, overwhelmed by an abundance of food and choices, only to realize that a very small percentage is actually food. You know, the kind without chemicals or preservatives that isn't meant to be put in the human body. I'm tired of resisting. Though physically more alert, I am tired. 

Good thing this (http://blip.tv/free-speech-tv/fed-up-2479751) movie just came out. Fed Up, which premiered at Sundance last week, is spreading awareness of Big Food's dominance. I don't feel so alone after all. Eery movie every blog, every article that comes out inspires me.

item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
This (http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/21/health/upwave-microwaving-food/index.html?hpt=hp_t2) article came out in CNN, raising an important issue that I personally wasn't aware of until 2 years ago, when my totes euro bf didn't even own a microwave at all!

I was surprised to see this article encouraged using microwave to cook food, if covered tightly in a microwave-safe contained with some liquid,

item.title: Why the Paleo Diet is BS
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2014/01/michael-pollan-paleo-diet-inquiring-minds
The more I read about food, the more I am convinced that diets don't work. I am suspicious of any diet, trend, or anything that tells you to restrict a certain food group. The Southbeach diet, the no-carb diet, and now the Paleo Diet are all unsustainable, restrictive ways to go about eating. I encourage you to read this article; Michael Pollan has a way of explaining complex ideas simply. If you don't feel like reading it though, here's a quick summary:
-Justifying daily consumption of meat by saying our hunter-gatherer ancestors did the same is wrong; our ancestors rarely ate meat, and they didn't have certain enzymes that we have today.
-We shouldn't completely avoid bread. Bread has nutrients from grains. Whole wheat and whole grain bread are rich in fiber.
-Fermented foods are good for us.
-A 100% raw food diet is not 100% healthy. Cooking can actually bring out nutrients in food.
-Cook! A cooked meal is almost always healthier than eating out.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Michael Pollan Explains What’s Wrong With the Paleo Diet

item.title: The Verdict on Canola Oil
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
Canola oil, or not to canola oil? That is the question.

I saw this in Harvard's dining hall today and was caught off guard; I'd previously read that canola oil was a big no-no. Considering canola oil is in so many foods I eat, I thought I'd do my own research. Here's what I came up with:

  • It was developed in Canada in the 60's and 70's, hence the name (canada and ola, aka "oil")
  • It is actually derived from the rapeseed, a deceivingly pretty yellow plant. Rapeseed oil is dangerous because it contains 54% erucic acid, which is toxic. 
  • While canola oil is regulated and cannot contain more than 2% erucic acid, it is still highly genetically modified.
  • Canola is one of the top (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/margie-kelly/genetically-modified-food_b_2039455.html) GMO crops.

 

 

[sources: http://customers.hbci.com/~wenonah/new/canola.htm,

http://www.getholistichealth.com/39005/watch-what-happens-in-your-body-when-you-eat-processed-food-video/

-created in Canada in the 60's and 70's (hence the name: canada and oil) from rapeseed, which is also used in the production of biofuels. 

-rapeseed oil is contains 54% ecucic acid, which is toxic. while canola oil is regulated and can only contain 2% ecucic acid, it is still not completely natural. Canola is one of the top (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/margie-kelly/genetically-modified-food_b_2039455.html) GMO crops. 

 

http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129010499

item.title: Wooo!
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
What a cool turn of events!
Last year I read the book "Sweet Poison: Why Sugar is Making Us Fat" by David Gillespie, a lawyer turned researcher and activist based in New Zealand. It totally changed the way I look at food and sugar and I highly recommend you read it! It was literally life changing; the moment I finished the book, I knew my eating habits were forever changed.
You can also check out the powerpoint I made summarizing what I learned, which I later presented to the bf. (https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1WXVEQiitDH8hEMqfSH16Uv-KHXgbiK3QSvSL1mdn7DE/edit?usp=sharing) . I now follow David's blog "Sweet Poison" on Facebook where I get lots of good information about nutrition (also recommended reading).
He recently started a new Facebook page dedicated exclusively to education. I was inspired by our shared interests and e-mailed him. I thanked him for the work he does and told him it's "nice to see someone else has the same interests; funny how they can intersect!" He just wrote back- he said thanks and wants to see the powerpoint I made! Cool!
Isn't it amazing how interconnected the world is? Never ceases to amaze me!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: What happened to Salty poison or is that just the foe of yesteryear?

item.title: Orange Juice: healthy or not so healthy?
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
I was talking nutrition with a friend over dinner last night. The conversation started with something like this:

Him: I don't understand why they serve half sized beers in Europe.

Me: They're actually regular sized beers, it's just our beers are double the size.

{interesting how the food industry has warped our perception of appropriate portion sizes]

--2 minutes later--

Him: I try to be healthy. I don't have sodas or juices. Except orange juice, because that's healthy.

 

The conversation stopped there, but I was tempted to continue. Is orange juice really healthy?

Some facts about OJ juice:

1) The label might say "100% orange juice" or "100% from concentrate", but this can be factually untrue. 

 

2) It's pasteurized, meaning it's boiled, de-areated, and stored for up to a year. Not as fresh as it is made to seem.

item.title: Yogurt: the good, the bad, and the ugly
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
(If you don't feel like reading, check out this video: http://www.upworthy.com/your-yogurt-has-more-sugar-than-a-coke-and-some-other-sneaky-food-stuff-you-didn-t-know-2) Light N Fit! Nonfat! 2x the protein! This yogurt is laden with smart marketing. But don't be fooled! Yogurt is one of those foods we automatically think is healthy. When I saw my friend eating this thinking she was having a healthy snack, I knew I had to snap some pics and inform the world that the yogurt you're probably eating is deceivingly bad for you. Check out the nutrition label: 7g of sugar-->that's 1/3 of your daily intake (for women, who should have about 20g/day) 0g fiber--> if you're going to have sugar, at least have some fiber with it, like whole grain breads Ingredients list: Fructose-->2nd listed ingredient. Ingredients are listed in descending order of predominance, so fructose is one of the main ingredients here. Fructose stimulates the release of a chemical in the brain that inhibits your ability to feel full, so eating fructose is like eating empty calories. When I read something has fructose, I imagine is having a label saying, "Eat me! You'll be hungry ten minutes later!" Other scientific words--> red flag

So what types of yogurts are good?

If you're looking for a healthy, protein-heavy snack, try a certified organic brand Greek yogurt, which should only have two ingredients: milk and active live cultures (also listed as Cultured Pasteurized Grade A Milk). Avoid yogurts with flavor or additives, including milk protein concentrate, gelatin kosher (a hidden source of MSG), whey protein concentrate, milk protein concentrate, organic corn starch. Most of yogurt is made from milk, so choose a yogurt where the milk is from pastured cows that are NOT given antibiotics or growth hormones. Chiobani was recently taken off the shelves of Whole Foods because the milk they use contains GMOs (the cows feed is derived from genetically engineered crops, like corn and soy beans). If you don't feel like looking through the ingredients, a quick rule of thumb is to avoid flavored yogurts. The "natural flavors" are manufactured using sketchy products- including wood pulp or macerated castor sac scent gland of a beaver (yes, the animal). Flavors also mean lots of unnecessary added sugar.

Summary of what to buy:

1) certified organic brand Greek yogurts. This ensures the yogurt is made from milk without antibiotics, growth hormones, or GMO feed. 2) plain yogurt, even if it's organic Greek yogurt. 3) yogurt with only 2 ingredients (milk + live active cultures). If you want, put some of your own fruit or nuts on top to make it more delicious. My mom and I spent a solid 15-20 minutes in the supermarket looking for a yogurt that fits the criteria; it's hard, I admit, but once you find the right brand, you won't have to go through the arduous decision-making process again. Don't be lazy, it's worth it for your health(y body + mind)! Sources: http://www.foodrenegade.com/, Non-GMO Project

item.title: Hot Water: A New Habit
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: Who says old dogs can't learn new tricks? In light of several recent inspirational conversations, I decided to pick up a new habit: drinking hot water with lemon. Not only is it perfect on a cold day, but it's delicious and healthy. I feel obliged to discuss my "inspirational conversations," in the hope that you'll be inspired to! 1) I was out to dinner with two Chinese friends recently who both ordered hot water before the meal. I hadn't seen that before and thought it was a bit strange but cool. Turns out there's a huge tea/hot water drinking culture out there, which also reminded me of a previous colleague who grew up on a tea farm in China. 2) My cognitive science professor told our professor that it's never too late to learn a new language. In fact, it's never too late to learn anything. You might not learn it as quickly- but with persistence and practice, you'll pick it up. While drinking hot water with lemon isn't a new skill, I like to think of it in the framework as "I'm not too old to acquire a new habit." Upon further research I learned that drinking water with lemon before meals is a great weight-loss tool because it the citric acid contained in the lemon helps to activate digestive enzymes and hormones associated with satiation triggers. It activates chemical signals to your brain that "enough is enough" while eating - the complete opposite of processed and refined foods. It detoxifies, cleanses, and rejuvenates. If you're afraid of the high acidity contained in lemons, just a small piece will do! (see below) Just make sure you put an actual lemon in and don't drink lemon juice (I felt compelled to say that; you never know in America what shortcuts people will come up with...) So in the spirit of new habits, I'm going to do some work over a hot cup of water with lemon and wait for the magic to happen! Did I mention it is also directly correlated with work performance? (I wish!)

item.title: Small Changes go a Long Way
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: Who says old dogs can't learn new tricks? In light of several recent enlightening conversations, I decided to pick up a new habit: drinking hot water with lemon. Not only is it perfect on a cold day, but it's yummy and healthy. I feel obliged to discuss my "inspirational conversations," in the hope that you'll be inspired too! 1) I was out to dinner with two Chinese friends who both ordered hot water before the meal. I thought it was a bit strange but intriguing. They told me all about the tea and hot-water-with-lemon culture in China; their culture believes in its ability to improve health by preventing sickness, increasing energy, and improving your skin. 2) My neuroscience/education professor told our class that it's never too late to learn a new language. In fact, he said, it's never too late to learn anything. You might not learn it as quickly, but with persistence and practice you'll pick it up. While drinking hot water with lemon isn't technically a new skill, I like to think of it in the framework as "I'm not too old to acquire a new habit." Upon further research I learned that drinking water with lemon before meals is a great weight-loss tool because the citric acid contained in the lemon helps to activate digestive enzymes and hormones associated with satiation triggers. It activates chemical signals to your brain that says "enough is enough" while eating - the complete opposite of processed and refined foods like white bread/rice, snacks, fast foods, etc. that trick your brain into thinking you're hungry. If you're afraid of the high acidity contained in lemons, just a small piece will do! Also, it's more effective if done on an empty stomach, like early in the morning or before a meal. So in the spirit of new habits, I'm going to do some work over a hot cup of water with lemon and wait for the magic to happen! Did I mention it is also directly correlated with good grades? (I wish!)

item.title: Sugar Research is Exploding!
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: “Sugar has adverse health effects above any purported role as ‘empty calories’ promoting obesity. Too much sugar doesn’t just make us fat; it can also make us sick.” -A recently published study* publicizing the negative effects of sugar. Big take-aways from the research: -added sugars are much worse for our health than natural sugars (i.e. processed or prepared foods, sugary drinks, prepared cereals  are a big no-no; fruit and natural fruit juices are ok). It may seem obvious, but the body of research showing the dangers of sugar is just starting to grow. -Recommendations for our daily allotment of sugar varies widely: added sugars should make up somewhere between 10-25% of our diet; we should limit our intake to 100 calories (for women) or 150 calories (for men). -15 countries have a tax for sugary drinks. Will the U.S. follow suit? Stay tuned... *http://archinte.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1819573

item.title: It's all over by the time you're 5
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
I'll never forget when my economics professor claimed that, "It's all over by the time you're age 5." While he was referring to return on investments of early childhood education, the comment can also apply to childhood obesity.

According to new study released this week, a child who enters kindergarten overweight has a 32% chance of becoming obese, 4 times the chance of normal-weight children. By the time a child enters kindergarten, much of the risk factors are already in place. In other words, if you make it to kindergarten without being heavy, your chances of being a normal weight for life are significantly better.

This study is a reminder of how important the first 5 years of life are. We must address obesity from a developmental standpoint and prevention efforts must begin much earlier than we originally thought.

Source: http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1309753?query=featured_home&

item.title: GuacaOLE
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky

item.title: Guaca-Olé!
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
A guy in my program made delicious guacamole for our cohort's retreat. It was the second time he'd made it, and it was so yummy I just had to ask for the recipe! Thanks Jeff!
 YUM!
2 large or 3 medium avocados
1 teaspoon chili powder
1 tablespoon lime juice
1 small white onion chopped finely
half teaspoon garlic chopped or mashed (better mashed)
salt and pepper to taste
Mix all and ya esta! You have yourself a party dish.
Did you know...avocados are really good for you?
Avocados are high in monosaturated fat, aka "the good fat," which lowers the bad type of cholesterol as well as your risk for heart disease and stroke. They have a relatively low amount of sugar compared to other fruits and more protein than most other fruits (4g protein/avocado, on average), so they're perfect for a snack. Avocados are an excellent source of potassium (more so than bananas!) and are full of good vitamins- good news for the waistline. AND finally, an avocado has about 11 grams of fiber- half your recommended daily intake. Perfect to add to a sandwich, eat plain, or for the recipe above!
For more...
---Listed #1 best fiber food here: http://www.dlife.com/diabetes/information/slide_show_pdf_files/new_pdfs/12_Best_Fiber_Foods.pdf
---Study on nutritional benefits here: http://www.nutritionj.com/content/12/1/1
---Detailed nutritional facts here: http://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/foods/show/2234?qlookup=09037&format=Full&max=25&man=&lfacet=&new=1

item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: Awesome article in The Economist explains the historically rooted differences in how Americans and Europeans see agriculture. In history, "Europeans fussed about appellations and where food came from. Americans 'treated food as commodities.' To this day, almost all corn and crops are genetically modified in the US but not in Europe. http://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21584994-why-american-agriculture-different-european-variety-farming-rocket-science

item.title: Why you Should Eat in Season
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded:
Quick question: When is the best time to buy broccoli? July or December? Yeah, I didn't know either. Why does it matter though?

**

Thanksgiving dinner was coming to a close, and a huge fruit platter sat on the buffet table for dessert. As everyone grabbed their fruit of choice, my boyfriend whispered in my ear, "Watermelon? In November?" Of course, being from Italy, he only eats watermelon in July and August- when they're in season. I hadn't even thought twice about eating watermelon in November. We're so used to any kind of food we want, whenever we want it, often overlooking the value of eating foods in in season. To clarify, when a food is in season, it means that's when it's naturally grown from the Earth. An orange doesn't grow in summer, so we shouldn't eat it then, for example. Watermelon grows in summer, so we should eat it then and only then. Here are some reasons why you should eat in season: 1) Cost. The relative abundance of the crop usually lowers the price. 2) Taste. Ever had a tomato that was mealy and granular? Gross. It probably wasn't in season, shipped in from afar, or grown in unnatural conditions. When a food is not in season locally, it is grown in a hothouse or shipped from other parts of the world, both affecting the taste. When a food is transported from another part of the world, they have to be harvested early and refrigerated during the trip so they don't rot, and therefore don't ripen as well as in their natural environment. They don't develop their full flavor. 3) Save Nutrients. A food that has endured the shipping process loses nutrients along the way. Buying something in season and locally ensures it has all its nutrients. 4) Sacrifice: Have no fear, there's always something in season! Check here: http://www.cuesa.org/eat-seasonally Sources & additional reading: 1 Book: Coming Home to Eat 2) http://life.gaiam.com/article/benefits-eating-what-s-season

item.title: Can beer be healthy?
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: Good news: Being healthy doesn't mean you have to avoid beer! It just means choosing the right ones- the ones without toxic and genetically modified ingredients that make us sick and perpetuate our sugar cravings. Fun fact: Beer is regulated by the Department of Treasury, not the Food and Drug Administration, which means listing ingredients is voluntary and guidelines overall are lax. That's why you don't see calories or percent alcohol listed on beers (except light ones). Many beers contain additives, including added sugars like high fructose corn syrup, caramel coloring, MSG, and calcium disodium EDTA containing formaldehyde, and more...gross. But have no fear! From my research, I found these to be the purest, chemical-free beers: Amstel Light, Heineken, and Sierra Nevada and locally made beer from microbreweries, which are more likely to produce pure beer and  organic beer. Avoid these: Budweiser, Budlight and Michelob Ultra (contain dextrose); Corona, Foster's, Miller Light, and Pabst (contain corn syrup); Newcastle (artificial caramel color that is banned in other countries). This is a gross simplification of beer and its ingredients, but the overall take-away from my research was that most beers contain GMOs, and that we should all feel confident having Heineken, Sierra Nevada, and Amstel Light as our go-to beers. (I promise they didn't pay me off to say that- though that would make for an interesting story!) Sources: http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s002170050478, http://www.care2.com/greenliving/toxic-and-gmo-ingredients-in-your-beer.html, Foodbabe

item.title: Overcoming Feelings of Powerlessness with Food
item.dc:creator: laurenswersky
item.content:encoded: I received bad news a few days ago: a friend's mom was diagnosed with cancer. Suddenly, out of nowhere. Ugh. With news like that, you can't help but feel completely helpless. Why her? What can we do now? How can we prevent this? Why is there no cure? and on and on. But the silver lining is this: as much as things may seem out of our hands, what is in our control is what we put in our bodies. To some extent, we can control the fate of our health by not putting chemicals and toxic substances in our bodies. News like this, news we've probably all had at one point, only reaffirms how important it is to adopt and maintain healthy habits: cooking food ourselves, and reading ingredient labels and avoiding anything with additives or chemicals. Being serious about not putting toxic carcinogens in our body. Of course, it's not easy to uncover what's in our food- cooking can be time consuming, and reading ingredient labels can be arduous- but if it means doing whatever we can to both feel good (and look good, if that motivates you) in the present and avoid unwanted health problems in the future, it's worth it. When you hear news like cancer, counting calories seems futile. Who cares about calories in moments like these? If I could give one message to everyone it would be: forget counting calories, but look at the ingredients and eat only REAL food. It is one of the few things we can actually control in a life full of uncertainty. Petition* to remove azodicarbonamide, a toxic chemical illegal in Europe and Australia, from our foods: http://action.ewg.org/p/dia/action3/common/public/?action_KEY=2070&tag=201403ADAActionActionCenter *Petitions work: that's why Subway committed to removing azodicarbonamide from their subs!
